Title: A complete subset of a metric space is closed?
Content: Supposing $A$ is a subset of a metric space $S$, it is simple enough to show that if $S$ is complete and $A$ is closed, that $A$ is complete. However, without being given that $S$ is complete, what would the proof of the converse be? (i.e. proving that if $A$ is complete, $A$ is closed)
AcceptedAnswer: Suppose $A \subset S$ is complete. To prove that $A$ is closed, it suffices to prove that if $(x_n)$ is a sequence of points of $A$ which converges to $x \in S$, then $x \in A$. So let $x_n$ be such a sequence. Since $x_n$ converges in $S$, it is a Cauchy sequence in $S$. Therefore $(x_n)$ is also a Cauchy sequence in $A$, so by completeness of $A$, there exists some $y \in A$ such that $x_n \to y$. Then by uniqueness of limits, we must have $y=x$, so $x \in A$. Thus $A$ is closed.
